title: Wednesday, 11th November, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hi there

PM

This is ML

PM

And this is a Black suited goon

11:01 am
PM

PM

There he is

PM

This is from Bryce's post on One Hyde Park, of course

11:02 am
PM

Which you should have read already

PM

If you haven't, it's here: http://ftalphavill...nto-knightsbridge/

PM

Very funny and very revealing

11:03 am
PM

How the hell residents of this place are able to avoid all the usual public disclosures -- such as how much you've paid for a property -- is beyond me

BE

Hm. Some people have criticised my "blurry" photos. Actually ..... I chose a blurry one deliberately to obscure the identity of the goon.

PM

(Super SWF -- the comments weren't working? Didnt know that)

11:03 am
BE

He's just hired muscle. He doesn't need to be drawn into this personally.

BE

Anyway, to summarise .....

BE

What happened was I wasted a lot of my own time.

11:04 am
BE

Then I decided to waste a lot of the readers' time.

BE

What's surprising is that the readers don't seem to mind.

PM

Come on Bryce, it's fascinating

11:04 am
BE

Fair enough. I'll endeavour to waste their time more often in future.

PM

Everyone loves this sort of detail

PM

I was in that part of town last night as it happens

11:05 am
PM

Deserted. Dead. Lifeless

BE

Yeah, it's bleak.

BE

Anyway. Approximately several dozen knowledgeable people have emailed me, giving all sorts of interesting details and leads, so perhaps there will be a follow-up.

11:06 am
PM

Excellent

BE

But not today. As we have other stuff with which to deal.

undefined
11:07 am
BE

We're up. FTSE wise, at least. Lots of results, not much else.

BE

FTSE ahead 0.4%, 25 points, at 6300.

BE

SABMiller the main support.

11:07 am
SABMiller PLC (SAB:LSE): Last: 4,087, up 110.5 (+2.78%), High: 4,089, Low: 4,000, Volume: 3.05m
PM

Deal is struck

PM

Bye bye SAB Miller

11:08 am
BE

Yup, all done. Molson side-deal agreed, price priced.

BE

The only drama left relates to the two offers on the table.

PM

Extraordinary deal machine, ABI

11:08 am
BE

So you, puny minority shareholder, can take £44 cash.

BE

Or you can try to take the cash-and-share alternative, which as of the open was worth £41.84.

BE

... So, a 4.9 per cent discount to the cash offer.

11:09 am
BE

That discount locks you in for five years

BE

But also gives you director nomination rights.

PM

eh?

11:10 am
BE

This is the offer specifically for Altria and the Santo family, of course.

BE

Who have various CGT-related reasons for preferring stock to cash.

BE

It was never intended to be taken up by small shareholders.

11:11 am
BE

But with the discount so narrow, it's not implausible for small shareholders to ... well, cause trouble basically.

BE

Still not clear why Inbev's many advisors didn't put in some kind of ratchet between the stock and cash offers.

BE

Should've been simple, was widely discussed, but didn't happen.

11:13 am
BE

(@doodlelogic: well, indeed. The right is, realistically, a theoretical one.)

PM

Given the size of this, should maybe share the tombstone

BE

Not a cheap team by any means.

PM

Well done everyone

PM

See, we don't only share tombstones when it's a screw up

11:14 am
BE

Ditto research. This is from RBC, detailing the raised synergies. In case anyone cares about those.

BE

The new pieces of information are on the US business and on synergies.
On the US business, MolsonCoors has entered into a definitive agreement with Anheuser-Busch InBev to purchase SABMiller's 58% stake in MillerCoors for a
total transaction value of $12bn, about 12.5x FY17E EBITDA (in line with our previous expectation).
On synergies, ABI is guiding for $1.4bn to be achieved over four years from completion, in addition to saving initiatives already in place at SABMiller and
requiring estimated one-off cash costs of approximately $0.9 billion, incurred in the first three years after completion. Synergies will come from Procurement and
engineering savings (20%), Brewery and distribution efficiency gains (25%), Best practice sharing (20%), Corporate headquarters and overlapping regional
headquarters (35%). In addition, ABI believes that additional revenue and cash flow synergies may be realised but these are not yet quantifiable "for reporting
under the City Code at this time".
The synergy number is about 9% of acquired sales (excluding JVs and Associates). We think SABMiller is already an efficient business and ABI is unlikely to
achieve synergies similar to Modelo (21%) or Anheuser-Busch (18%). That said, at 9% we think the company could be low-balling the total number.

BE

Anyway. Sad to see SAB go. They hosted good lunches. There was a really good one at the Savoy a few years ago.

11:15 am
BE

Doubt Inbev will be extending similarly generous invites.

undefined
PM

Hey the grocers

11:16 am
PM

We havent done the grocers for ages

PM

Interims from Sainsbury

PM

Waddya reckon?

11:16 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 262.50, down 10.1 (-3.71%), High: 279.00, Low: 261.90, Volume: 6.04m
BE

Hm. PBT is ahead of where the consensus was.

BE

But it doesn't follow through into the full year, as it's all cost rather than trading.

11:17 am
PM

(Leggie -- the list of advisers just the tombstone)

BE

Bit of caution that second half won't be as easy as the first, which was on non-repeatable stuff, hence shares lower. That's how I read it anyway.

PM

ok

11:19 am
BE

Here's how Barclays reads it.

BE

Key numbers:

· Retail EBIT of €332mn versus Bloomberg consensus €309mn and Barclays €306mn, margin of 2.7% versus consensus and Barclays of 2.5%

· Underlying PBT of £308mn versus consensus of £294mn and Barclays £284mn

BE

First impressions:

· Retail EBIT margin contracted by 39bps in 1H15/16 to 2.71%, better than our and consensus estimate of c60bps margin decline. On a constant fuel price basis, margins contracted by -45bps in 1H.

· It appears that the outperformance is driven by a combination of more efficient promotional spend and good work on cost savings (FY guidance on cost savings has been increased from £200m to £225m).

· The only obvious negative – and it’s not huge – is that the transition costs to move the Bank onto Sainsbury’s platform will be at the top end of the £340-380m guidance range.

· Core retail capex was £301mn in 1H15/16, down £256mn y-o-y representing 2.2% of ex-fuel retail sales in 1H15/16 – the company targets 2% of sales over the years ahead by cutting capex to around £550mn in FY15/16.

· Net debt (treating perpetual securities as debt) stood at £2,351mn at end of 1H, in-line with the £2,343mn at end of FY14/15. Net pension deficit reduced from £651mn at end of FY14/15 to £473mn.

· Interim dividend of 4p stood basically in-line with consensus expectations of 4.1p.

· The estimated market value of Sainsbury’s property has fallen slightly to £10.8bn (from £11.1bn in March).

· PBT clearly better than expected, but unlike the trading statement in early October there is no explicit statement on the guidance, so we think the 1H beat is primarily a phasing issue.

11:20 am
BE

(@Roddy: the coffee granules in meat sauce thing is a common trick in commercial kitchens. Sainsbury's mistake was thinking we could handle the truth.)

BE

And SocGen.

BE

Main surprises Sainsbury’s delivered H1 15-16 PBT of £308m (-18%), ahead of
consensus £294m. Underlying EBIT £366m, indicating barely 40bp erosion in the Retail
EBIT margin, a resilient trend given price investment (£150m global plan). We note very
strict cost cutting with a new target for this year of £225m (vs £140m in 2014-15), o/w
£115m achieved in H1. Interim dividend 4.0p, in line with consensus.
Potential impact on SG & market forecast We do not expect any significant change to
consensus in light of today’s numbers given that consensus PBT had already been revised
up by 5% since publication of Q2 sales on 30 September from £548m to £573m. This
upgrade was driven by management’s revised guidance on the back of ‘sales and cost
savings ahead of expectations’.
Potential impact on share price/recommendation The group appears confident in its
own differentiation and strengthens, echoing the positive message delivered with Q2 sales.
We think J. Sainsbury is the best placed of the Big Four players to protect its market
positions and profitability. Our target price is based on the average of a peer comparison
(315p, 20% P/E discount to European peers) and a DCF (312p, WACC 8.2%, perp. growth 1.5%, norm. EBIT margin 3.2% as of 2022-23e).

11:21 am
BE

So, yeah, not terribly exciting.

BE

(@Soundbuy: we prefer the term "plongeur".)

undefined
11:22 am
BE

Otherwise on results, TalkTalk rallies.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 239.80, up 22.5 (+10.35%), High: 246.10, Low: 235.00, Volume: 5.08m
PM

How and why?

11:23 am
BE

That's a very good question.

PM

Brand tarnished

PM

Seriously tarnished

11:23 am
BE

The threat of the divi going -- which was Citi's idea, no one else's -- proves unfounded.

BE

And management made confident noises about damage limitation.

PM

Ah, that would have provoked panic

11:24 am
PM

Guess the hacking bill is not as high as it could have been

PM

£35m or so

BE

Thing is, the first order effects of hacking were never going to be that high.

11:24 am
BE

Fines are miniscule.

BE

Customers are lazy. Systems to deter them from breaking contracts are complicated.

BE

What you need to worry about is the second order effects.

11:26 am
BE

Ie, it's whether long term customer numbers will support the economies of scale that are built into the TalkTalk guidance.

BE

Guidance that wasn't reiterated today.

BE

No mention of the 25% margin target.

11:26 am
BE

So while the shares have rallied off a record low, it's hard to view much here as objectively positive.

PM

hang on -- hadn't appreciated this.

PM

TalkTalk's dividend is totally uncovered

11:27 am
BE

Yeah.

PM

Free cash flow 27m

PM

Dividends out 85m

11:27 am
BE

And note, that even before the hack TalkTalk doesn't seem to have been doing very well.

BE

We've mentioned a few times its rather aggressive price rises. Four or five hikes over the past couple of years, I think.

BE

And we've mentioned that the barriers to switching to someone cheaper are now very very low, thanks to Ofcom. Takes two minutes.

11:29 am
BE

In what is an extremely competitive market. Even more so now Vodafone is trying to muscle in.

PM

Welcome

BE

Mixed 1H15/16 with revs ahead but EBITDA below already modest
expectations. Mgmt expects to incur £30-35m of incremental cost related to the
cyber-attack, half of which we think will be exceptional. Cons will need to mark
down FY15/16 EBITDA by 5-7% to accommodate the non-exceptional part.
Company says it remains 'confident in a material increase in profits in FY17 and
beyond' but there is no mention of longstanding 25% target in today's release.

11:30 am
BE

Mixed 1H15/16 results with revs ahead, EBITDA below. 2Q revs GBP464m are 1.5%
ahead of JEFe with y/y growth accelerating from 3.5% 1Q to 5.9% 2Q. The largest part of
the seq pick-up comes from corporate where growth accelerated from 4.9% 1Q to 8.0%
2Q. Corporate revs have previously been boosted by carrier voice rather than higher margin
products. We see that carrier revs were +34% in 1H15/16. On-net consumer rev growth also
improved from +6.5% y/y 1Q15/16 to +8.6% 2Q. However, 1H15/16 EBITDA is below even
our modest expectations: GBP90m vs JEFe GBP99m. Implies an 18% EBITDA decline with
margin down to 9.9% vs 12.6% in 1H14/15. BB net loss -80k stands in sharp contrast to
peers, although TalkTalk highlights 72k deliberate disconnections (an issue it flagged at the
Oct investor day). That said, BB growth will have benefitted from migrating customers away
from the Tesco consumer BB business. TalkTalk is not disclosing how many Tesco migrations
took place in 1H. It says that, in overall terms, BB net adds turned positive in 2Q. We have
confirmed this morning that 2Q is when the Tesco migration got underway. Churn has
inflected upwards, albeit slightly to 1.5% in 1H (vs 1.4% 1H last year).

BE

Cyber-attack cost. TalkTalk says the cyber-attack issue will cause it to incur GBP30-35m of
incremental cost. This includes cost of providing subs with a ‘free upgrade’ in compensation
for their recent experiences. Upgrades could include free landline calls for 12 months or
Sky Sports for 3 months. We think that around half the GBP30-35m cost will be booked
as exceptional this year. Clean of these cyber-attack costs, TalkTalk says FY15/16 results
should be in line with pre-attack consensus (EBITDA GBP295m pre-exceptionals). However,
consensus will need to mark FY15/16 headline EBITDA estimates down for the GBP15-20m
of cyber-attack cost that is not treated as exceptional. Implies 5%-7% downgrade.

BE

No mention of 25% FY16/17 margin in this morning’s release. The longstanding
25% target for FY16/17 EBITDA margins is not mentioned anywhere in this morning’s 26-
page release. The company simply states that ‘we remain confident in a material increase in
profits in FY17 and beyond’. The 25% target was mentioned in the corresponding release
post-FY results in May.

11:30 am
BE

Leverage. Net Debt/EBITDA at 2.8x (2.4x FY14/15) crept up this quarter as a result of both
softer EBITDA and the timing of dividend/capex payments. In today's release mgmt say they
expect FY16 Net Debt/EBITDA at the year end to be lower than at the end of H1 excluding
the impact of the cyber attack. Pre today's results we forecast FY16 Net Debt/EBITDA of 2.4x,
including an extra £35m of cost increases this to 2.7x at Mar 2016.

BE

Dividend policy maintained. A confident move is to maintain previous dividend policy.
Interim DPS +15% to 5.29p (in-line with JEFe) and FY DPS guided +15% as well (also in line).
Analyst meeting 9am. Key issues are (1) whether TalkTalk can maintain policy of
aggressively pricing up legacy subs to fund promotions for new connections given the
treatment that the legacy base has been experiencing, (2) how credibly it can reassert
conviction in the cost-cutting step up needed to reach 25% margins during FY16/17 (if that
target still holds), and (3) what mgmt thinks the implications might be if the enquiries into its
security currently underway find that controls were weaker than could have been expected.

BE

Haven't heard back from the analyst meeting yet.

11:31 am
PM

This feels inherently unstable

BE

Yeah, @nichoman mentions bid spec, which is constant.

BE

As I understand it, Vodafone, Sky and the like all have models showing whether it's cheaper to buy TalkTalk's customers or just erode its market share with predatory pricing.

11:33 am
BE

But, given the increased uncertainty about how many customers TalkTalk will have by this time next year, I'd assume those models are not getting referred to much at the moment.

undefined
PM

Frontier Developments

11:33 am
PM

How's taht doing this morning?

PM

Steady at 240p

PM

Numis have a note out this morni9ng

11:34 am
PM

Kicked off coverage

PM

let me get it

PM

david Toms

11:34 am
PM

Frontier's launch of Elite: Dangerous nearly one year ago has, in our view, been
very successful with almost a million units sold. Our analysis of video game
performance over the past decade suggests at least a 10-20% probability that Elite
will therefore spawn a highly valuable multi-year franchise which could be worth
900p/share. Frontier is, in our view, a beneficiary of a major structural shift in the
economics of the sector as video game distribution migrates online. Our research
shows that direct digital distribution of games to customers is potentially highly
favourable for developers such as Frontier, providing them with an opportunity for
a four-fold increase in revenue. It also eliminates revenue leakage to piracy and preowned
games, which in turn markedly improves the risk/reward ratio for the launch
of new titles by reducing the need for large upfront expenditure. Our 337p target
price is based on 9.1x CY17 PE, derived from the 5-year average trough multiple of
the peer group applied to a weighted combination of our base case (80%), upside
(10%) and downside scenarios (10%).

PM

Did you get a chance to try this thing at Camp AV?

BE

I didn't. Irritatingly.

11:35 am
PM

(I didn't -- but others said it was terrific)

PM

Here's more from Toms

PM

Major industry shift. The video game industry is moving towards direct digital
distribution, which potentially gives 50-100% of a title's retail price to its developer vs
the 10-20% achieved with a normal publisher/retailer model. Frontier's business model
has been developed entirely around such new channels to market; with an added
benefit being the absence of pre-owned games leading to a launch process that does
not need to be concentrated in just a few weeks. In turn this de-risks investments in
marketing and stock and allows volume to build over time.
● Strong franchise developing. Frontier's first franchise, Elite: Dangerous, has got off
to a strong start in our view, with nearly 1m units sold in its first full year. We think the
key test for this franchise will be to see second-year volumes tracking ahead of year
one, demonstrating the kind of profile associated with successful multi-year franchises.
Frontier has two further franchises planned, with the first ("Planet Coaster") due to
launch in Q4 2016.
● Significant potential upside. If one of Frontier's titles makes it into the 10-20% that
become growing multi-year franchises, our 337p target price could see significant
upside to over 900p/share. The key risk with a developer like Frontier is that it fails to
produce high quality titles and thus does not achieve expected sales levels.

11:36 am
PM

Actually, there's 30 pages of this?

PM

Maybe find its way to the usual place...

PM

Love this header on this

11:36 am
PM

They dont even bother to hide it in the small print

PM

PM

BUY

11:37 am
PM

Silly isn't it, really?

PM

Can't call research research

BE

Yeah. "For FCA purposes" is basically a shorthand for "they're making us say this".

11:38 am
undefined
BE

Scanning down requests, of which there aren't many ..........

BE

Someone mentioned SSE, which I didn't think was wildly exciting.

11:39 am
BE

You're still getting the divi, which is surely the only reason to hold SSE.

BE

H1 a small beat, H2 a small risk.

PM

(bones30 -- we have nothing fresh on Eros. To be honest, backed away in the face of fierce bear raiders, who seem to have done a lot of homework. That said, they keep coming out with stupid tweets such as "Head shot coming" and then there's nothing fresh. just mutterings about governance. It's an indian company -- of course governance is going to be an issue...)

11:40 am
BE

Deutsche's conventionally good on the utilities. Here's what they say.

BE

SSE reported H1 results ahead of our estimates, mainly due to a better performance in the retail division. However, retail profits are still expected by the company to be down yoy while falling gas and power prices in the wholesale market make commodity conditions challenging. SSE has announced a further 500MW reduction of coal power capacity, showing the pain in the generation market. Despite the weak commodities, the good performance of regulated networks and lack of any acceleration in customer losses is supportive. Hold.

BE

SSE reported H1 results c. £45m ahead, mainly on the retail business but the cautious tone on H2 means FY consensus is unlikely to move up significantly. Operating profit was £702m vs DB £658m, adjusted PBT was £548m vs DB £501m and EPS of 45.9p was 8.5% ahead of DB 42.3p. The better retail profits were due partly to colder weather than normal, but customer losses also slowed, to co 5% yoy,, which we found encouraging. The DPS was up 1.1% to 27.1p which is perhaps a little disappointing and below our hoped for 1.9%. However, this is still above the currently low RPI inflation. SSE reiterated its expectations that FY adjusted EPS would be at least 115p/share (DBE 116.5p on the SSE basis, or 102p after pension finance costs and deferred tax).

11:41 am
BE

SSE has said that it will reduce transmission contracted coal capacity at Fiddlers Ferry by c. 500MW to just under 1500MW from April next year. This will save SSE transmission capacity costs but will further reduce available coal capacity in the market next year (with around 5000MW of other announced closures). While this may ultimately tighten the market and help to lift prices it shows the severe pain being endured by UK coal capacity against a backdrop of falling gas prices and increased carbon taxes. The results of the generation capacity auction on 8 December could trigger further closure decisions in the medium term.

BE

Overall we continue to rate SSE a Hold. Its long term track record of dividend growth is impressive and its regulated networks continue to make excellent returns despite the step down in electricity distribution profits this year from the new 8 year price control. Offsetting this is an extremely challenging backdrop for market-exposed businesses with SSE’s clean hydro and wind generation seeing lower revenues from gas-linked power prices, and competitive and regulatory pressures limiting the retail margin.

SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,459, down 33 (-2.21%), High: 1,510, Low: 1,457, Volume: 1.15m
11:42 am
BE

And Jefferies.

BE

Comment: SSE continues to manage its way through challenging markets. The company
faces considerable profit pressures in wholesale due to low power prices and in retail
due to competition. SSE's network business and renewable portfolio partly mitigate
these pressures, although SSE's return on capital continues to suffer. In our view, SSE's
commitment to grow its DPS by at least RPI is sustainable through 2016/17. However, unless there is a material recovery in power prices and spark spreads, then SSE will eventually be forced to choose between its investment program and its dividend.

BE

(@Penny: it stands for "give a fig".)

11:42 am
undefined
BE

What else? Sellside very dull this morning.

BE

Unless you're interested in Jimmy Choo, which barely trades

11:43 am
BE

Due in part to a very small free float

BE

Though I think the lock-up on JAB is now off.

BE

And given JAB's recent sales of most of the stuff in its portfolio that isn't coffee, it wouldn't be hugely surprising to see an exit or a reduction quite soon.

11:45 am
BE

That's speculation, though. What is happening is that Liberum's gone cautious.

BE

Got cold feet, if you like.

BE

The speed of the luxury slowdown is notable and yet to be discounted in Choo’s consensus forecasts, in our view. We see Burberry as a bellwether and estimate that sales in China fell from -2% in calendar Q2 to -11% in Q3, and in the US from +8% to -7%. Others have seen a similar shape to trading. We believe Choo faces increased competition in shoes as other luxury goods companies chase growth. We cut ‘15e & '16e EBIT forecasts by 19% and our rating from Buy to Hold. New TP 160p, from 210p.

11:46 am
BE

With competition increasing, Choo is increasing its high fashion range and retains its top rating in the fashion press. Caution leads us to cut GM forecasts to reflect markdown risk.

BE

Choo’s brand strength in the US and Europe, and growing strength in Asia underpins a sound long term strategy with white space into which to grow.

BE

We estimate that Burberry’s US sales fell from +8% in calendar Q2 to -7% in Q3, and in Asia from -2% to -11%. This is very sudden and is at the heart of our forecast downgrade.

11:46 am
BE

Reduced TP of 160p based on new forecasts. Even on downgraded forecasts Choo’s 3yr EPS CAGR remains at a premium to the sector at 8.9% vs 7.0%. DCF support at 166p.

BE

Note, incidentally, the truly awful numbers yesterday from Chow Tai Fook

BE

As in, the jewellery bit of CTF.

11:47 am
BE

Reporting that sales in Hong Kong and Manilla have absolutely cratered.

BE

Not a great indicator for Burberry, which has interims tomorrow I think.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,324, up 5 (+0.38%), High: 1,332, Low: 1,314, Volume: 943.56k
11:48 am
BE

(@Urgeview: certainly. What's HCM?)

undefined
BE

Oh! Hutchison China Meditech!

11:49 am
Hutchison China MediTech Ltd (HCM:LSE): Last: 2,610, down 57.5 (-2.16%), Volume: 3.95k
PM

I have nothing on it

BE

Um, no. Panmure follow, I think. And it's an Edison client.

11:50 am
BE

I'm starting cold here, sorry. Come back tomorrow.

undefined
BE

Sophos, however, we can do.

11:51 am
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 270.00, up 18.2 (+7.23%), High: 274.00, Low: 261.20, Volume: 820.65k
BE

A software company with an unorthodox approach to adding up its numbers.

PM

hahaha

11:52 am
BE

Which, I guess, sector investors are becoming more relaxed about.

BE

Today we get an upgrade. Not to cashflow, of course, but that's never been a metric management consider worth focusing on.

BE

Morgan Stanley has all the detail.

11:54 am
BE

Strong billings growth sustains into 2Q: Sophos reported 1H16 billings of
$242m, +24% l-f-l. This was 13% ahead of MS as Sophos was able to sustain a
20% plus billings growth run-rate into 2Q, despite a tougher base comp
(+16% vs. +9%). The star performer again was Network, which was able to
sustain the 34% 1Q billings growth into 2Q. Network billings were 8% ahead
of MS. However, End-user billings were also strong - up 15% in 1H l-f-l, after
+16% in 1Q. This was 3% above MS. Other billings were +21% l-f-l. By type,
hardware billings were strongest, +64%, with subscription billings +17%. The
strong hardware billings (recognised up-front) meant reported revenues were
also strong - +17% l-f-l at $234m. This was 12% above MS. We do not view
the strong hardware billings as a negative as this was driven by very strong
new customer additions in UTM (unified threat management, +60%), which
gives Sophos significant cross and up sell opportunities in future.

BE

EBITDA well ahead of MS, FCF slightly ahead: Sophos reported cash
EBITDA of $45.5m, a margin of 18.8% and 18% above MS. Adj. EBITDA was
$38m, a margin of 16.1% and 80% above MS. Margins declined slightly y/y, as
expected, as the phasing of marketing investments is more balanced in FY16
vs. weighted to 2H in FY15. Unlevered adj. FCF was $19.9m, ahead of MS
($17.2m). FCFF was impacted slightly y/y as capex investments were more
weighted to 1H16. We expect this to reverse in 2H16.

BE

Outlook raised for the FY: After a strong 1H, Sophos has raised its FY16
guidance for both billings and cash EBITDA margins. Sophos now expects l-f-l
billings to grow in the high-teens to 20% (vs. in the mid-teens previously). The
company expects cash EBITDA margins to slightly exceed last year's level
(21.3%) vs. not come in below that level previously. While cash EBITDA
margins were down slightly in 1H16, the company has a much easier base of
comparison in S&M spending in 2H, underpinning the confidence on margin
improvement for the FY.

11:55 am
BE

Product momentum continues, new customers ramp, cross-selling and
renewals improve: Sophos has announced the launch of two key products, in
addition to the usual product enhancements. The company has announced the
availability of Sophos Security Heartbeat (the project that was code named
Galileo) which aims to share intelligence between network and end-user
security. Sophos XG Firewall also went GA (generally available) - the
combination of the UTM / NGFW (next generation firewall) technologies from
Cyberoam and Sophos (the project that was code named Copernicus). We view
these as further underpinning the company's future growth expectations. In
addition, we would also note that sales to new customers increased to 25%
from 22% and the number of customers with both UTM and Endpoint
protection increased to 6.4% from 4.6%.

BE

MS forecasts: We raise our billings forecasts by 2% in FY16 and 1% in FY17.
Our cash EBITDA increases by 1% and 2% (FY16/17) while adj. EBITDA goes up
by 10% and 6% due to more up front revenue recognition (more hardware
billings in 1H16). Our FCFF increases by 2% in FY16 and is unchanged in FY17.
Our price target is based on EV/FCFF and so remains unchanged at 300p.

Fenner PLC (FENR:LSE): Last: 140.68, down 13.32 (-8.65%), High: 148.00, Low: 140.68, Volume: 541.21k
BE

Investec says ...........

BE

Price: 154p | Target: Under Review | Rec: Sell
Fenner has faced deteriorating markets for the last two years and the momentum is still downwards. The FY15 results were close enough to much-reduced expectations, but the outlook still requires a ‘moderate’ downward adjustment to guidance. We expect that FY16 consensus will be reduced by c.10% and we still see risk to the dividend (maintained for now and yielding almost 8%). On the expectation of lower estimates and given a PE-based valuation (currently under review), we reiterate our Sell recommendation.

Trading. Cost control in both operations and selective investment in AEP were the main themes of FY15, with market conditions providing very little cheer. Revenue declined by 9% (14% in ECS) and operating profits were down by 29%, in spite of management’s best efforts. The result for the year was close enough to our expectations, although these have been reduced 15 times in the last two years. However, conditions continue to deteriorate in the US coal industry and Fenner is guiding lower for FY16 as a result. Its ‘moderate’ change is unquantified, but we expect c.10%, and restructuring initiatives are to be announced soon.
Outlook. Fenner has taken a further £24.5m impairment charge (the same as in the prior year), which will have been based on expected future cash flows. In spite of the anticipated lower capex outflows (following completion of projects in AEP), we do not believe that earnings or cash flow will fully justify the current level of dividend distribution and we therefore maintain lower dividend estimates, notwithstanding the decision to pay 12.00p in respect of FY15.
Stance. Until we see end-market stability, it will be difficult to be confident in estimates for Fenner, and therefore to believe a valuation of the shares based on earnings. Clearly, we have not yet reached that point, so we maintain a Sell recommendation, with our detailed estimates and target price placed under review.
